title: How many Eritrean citizens will apply for asylum in Europe for the first time in the first quarter of 2016?
preds: Unless something is drastically wrong with the numbers I've been watching, this estimate stays the same.
Putting 2% more on the (<10) option, taking away from (10-15)

http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/download.php?id=864 Based on Fig 8, there seem to be less Eritrian arrivals to Italy in 2016, than in 2015, based on January comparisons.  The level also is well below the rate needed to reach 10,000 based on prior year trends.  Naval focus on sea traveling refugees to Italy since the well publicized death last year may have reduced the rate.

I remain  at my previous forecast although, but do believe  the number looks to closer to 10'000 rather than 5'000 for Q1. 
Q closes 31.3.16 HT to @Rene for running basic BDR & Dutch numbers. Motivated me to do extra work this Good Friday morning.  Have  come up w/ following: 1. 3. 4/3/15 Eurostat news release states in 2015 over 1.2mn 1st time asylum seekers registered in EU member states. NB: chart breaks down 33K were Eritrean. http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/documents/2995521/7203832/3-04032016-AP-EN.pdf/790eba01-381c-4163-bcd2-a54959b99ed6 ; which works out per quarter last year slightly over 8'000. Admittedly, a v rough calculation considering the seasonal flow ( January-March passage over the dangerous Sea is lower than the summer/fall months).  The  EUROSTAT dated is 4 March this year. The colder winter months of January/February are usually a minor deterrent to the more dangerous Mediterranean route Eritreans appear to use.  More generally, but also relevant are new releases as well that go to broader issues: 1mn or more w/in next year that also indirectly address the Eritreans and, the routes they take: 
2. 3/22/16: IOM in Geneva confirms THRU 20/3/16 160K arrivals by sea. 147K Greece, 13K ITALY. http://www.iom.int/news/mediterranean-migrant-arrivals-2016-160547-deaths-488
3.  Notes in report: "...IOM reports from Italy about 1200 migrants arrived by sea LAST weekend...the majority of them are Western Africans, Eritreans, Sudanese & Moroccans.." So, the 13K number includes this last weekend report from IOM.
Raising due to short remaining time.

The numbers for February 2016 (the Netherlands and Germany, popular destinations for asylum applicants from Eritrea): The Netherlands: 71 new applicants in February (17 a year ago)
Source: https://ind.nl/Documents/AsylumTrends%20feb%202016.pdf Germany: 920 new applicants. This year so far 1556 (last year: 1016)
Source: http://www.bamf.de/SharedDocs/Anlagen/DE/Downloads/Infothek/Statistik/Asyl/201602-statistik-anlage-asyl-geschaeftsbericht.html?nn=1694460 (Sorry for the sloppy numbers, both reports are not quite compatible and I'm to tired/lazy to check the older reports) I do not believe that 10,000 will be reached. My guess would be around 6,000.

The pace of crossings to Italy has picked up this month, but it looks like the number for Q1 is going to be well under 5,000 http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php#_ga=1.1515249.1734802494.1454954886
Anyone seen any figures for UK and France for Jan or Feb 2016? http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/submitViewTableAction.do
More or less following consensus on this one.

So far Europe has seen 153,00 refugees and migrants during Q1[a]. If I read the data correctly, less 1% of these refugees and migrants have been from Eritrea. Why? Guinea, Senegal, and Morocco are identified as providing more refugees and migrants than Eritrea (which is not in the top 10), and the former 3 are also listed as providing less than 1% of the total 153k. All of that suggests (if I'm not falling on my face somewhere) that there have been less than 1,500 Eritrean refugees and migrants to Europe in Q1, making it highly unlikely that we'll see anything like 10,000 or even 15,000 in Q1. -- [a] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php
Distance and costs are an issue....
http://lenews.ch/2016/03/10/swiss-asylum-numbers-down-sharply-in-february/ Switzerland reported asylum requests from Eritrea in February were 181, down  from 233 February last year.

I read the first page of "top" comments (maybe 10), and then I extremized for myself :)  .  Lots of very compelling data and analysis for the <10k case here, from multiple perspectives.  Never say never, but seems like a v good bet to me.

First quarter is always really slow. Asylum applications peak in the summer months. Q1 2014 had 3,045. Q1 2015 had 3,580. That for the EU. Numbers from Eurostat site.  An interesting article about the people-smuggling business from Eritrea to Europe: http://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/migration/#story/34

The data appears to be highly seasonal, with Q1 being more like 3000 refugees on average, even if it exceeds 10,000 on occasion in other quarters. A very mild winter, and/or an extreme event might just make this possible, the former having more effect than the latter.

1. UN estimates 5k Eritreans flee country per month - grossing up to 15K a quarter (http://www.wsj.com/articles/eritreans-flee-conscription-and-poverty-adding-to-the-migrant-crisis-in-europe-1445391364) However, there is a success rate implied: They may day or give up, so the number must be below 15k. Now, I know the route from Eritreia to Europe is quite dangerous, as seen in several news articles, apart from the one above, that states 3k eritreans drowning in one year, so I would assume 3k over 5k * 12 months mortality = 5% Then I will assume very few of them give up mid-journey, about another 5% of them. So in this approach, 15k * (1 - 5% - 5%) = 13.5k 2. It seems one of the preferred regions of eritreans is Italy (from the WSJ article), which received over 35k eritrean migrants in 2015 (https://www.iom.int/news/mediterranean-update-migrant-deaths-rise-3329-2015), roughly 9k a quarter. But this is just Italy, so this number should be higher than 9k for the entire Europe. Assuming 80% of eritreans go to Italy, which is a good representation for majority (using Paretto principle), then 9k / 80% = 11.3k which gets near the estimation #1 3. Asylum applications: Now, after all that estimation to check how many will arrive at an european country, it is time to see how many will actually apply for Asylum. 
According to http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/File:Five_main_citizenships_of_(non-EU)_asylum_applicants,_2015_(number_of_first_time_applicants,_rounded_figures)_YB16.png, 32k Eritreans applied to major EU countries, roughly 8k per quarter However, the list above is not including eritreans in Italy, the preferred country by sea, so this is conflicting - there must be a relevant ammount of applicants, though not reaching the top 5 nationalities, so we've got a base of 8k + a number ranging from 1 to a couple of thousands, which may very well get to the 10-15k range.
Very small changes to my forecast, as I've seen no evidence that Eritrean asylum seekers will break the 10,000 barrier in Q1.
The preliminary numbers on this question indicate about 1200 Eritrean citizens have made this journey. At this rate, the number will not exceed 10K by end of month.

Not sure why I had it at 100% before, but still fully confident it will remain under 10k, considering there were only 995 Eritrean citizens applying for asylum for the first time in January 2016 (though I'm not sure if that number will be updated or not): http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/asylum-and-managed-migration/data/main-tables

Number of first time applicants in the Netherlands in January 2016 was 93, compared to 28 in January 2015. That's 3.32 times as much. However, in Germany the numbers are 627 vs. 620 (see link below, table on top of page 4 of report), not much of a difference. Sources: The Netherlands: PDF, first link on this page: https://ind.nl/organisatie/jaarresultaten-rapportages/rapportages (Direct link: https://ind.nl/Documents/Asylum%20Trends%20jan%202016.pdf ) Germany: http://www.bamf.de/SharedDocs/Anlagen/DE/Downloads/Infothek/Statistik/Asyl/201601-statistik-anlage-asyl-geschaeftsbericht.html?nn=1694460 There are also new numbers from Belgium. Not a lot of first-time applicants from Eritrea there (29) See http://www.cgvs.be/nl/actueel/asielstatistieken-januari-2016 (there's a link to the pdf on the bottom of the page)
Adjusting to close in on Anneinak and stay ahead of the trend.
Base on current stats and current events.

WSJ article/Council on foreign relations: 5000 leave Eritrea per month, and 17000 requested asylum in the first 8 months of 2015.
Say, 2000 per month x3=6000. Unlikely to get as high as 15000, as this would suggest everyone leaving Eritrea goes to the EU. Breaching 10000 seems possible though depending on seasonal conditions.
Talking non EU countries into account.

3 reasons.  1. TIme of year is not ideal for moving to Greece or Italy. 2.  Route through Libya to Italy is less of an option with the civil war in Libya. 3.  Word getting out that unless you are Syrian or Iraqi you are not granted automatic refugee status in much of Europe.

Looking at the EU statistics of 2012/13 and 14/15 there seemed to have been always a dip in the first quarter. The problem I see with this question if Europe is meant as the EU or including non EU countries like Switzerland. If it does I will have to increase my estimate on 10k to 15k slightly an dreduce the less than 10'000.
Steps are being taken to curb the flow of irregular migrants from the North and Horn of Africa. This will lower the flow.

I'm just slightly modifying my forecast on word that "Eritrea is not prepared to stop forcing its youth into lengthy stretches of work as soldiers and civil servants, a conscription policy that is driving waves of refugees to make the perilous trip across the Sahara desert and Mediterranean Sea to Europe"[1]. @cdob63 and others mention that this article reports that "Each month as many as 5,000 people flee Eritrea according to U.N. figures." Good find, but the number of Eritrean migrants who try to come to Europe varies seasonally (probably because of difficulties crossing the Mediterranean during poor weather and in less than fully sea-worthy vessels), and last year it was at its lowest during Q1. So I think the number is much more likely to be south of 10,000. --- [1] http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eritrea-politics-insight-idUSKCN0VY0M5

http://www.wsj.com/articles/eritreans-flee-conscription-and-poverty-adding-to-the-migrant-crisis-in-europe-1445391364?mg=id-wsj According to UN, 9% of 4.5 million flee and 1 in 50 apply in Europe. That is about 8,000. I assume that those who flee are new applicants and perhaps some residing in other countries may apply for the first time as well. Given the uncertainty about how the number will be calcluated I think it is not unreasonable that over 10,000 will apply. Especially given the recent announcement to continue conscription.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eritrea-politics-insight-idUSKCN0VY0M5 This story suggests Eritreans are leaking out at 5k/month or maybe more, and the rate may accelerate since Asmara has backed out of some agreements related to why people are leaving (a long term of compulsory military or other service).  Not all who leave are going to Europe, and not all who go to Europe will necessarily be applying for asylum.  Mightn't take much to bump the numbers into the middle group, though.
Up the final 5% for top bucket.

TASS reports that according to Welt am Sonntag (i.e., the Sunday edition of Die Welt): "Some 200,000 refugees now are staying along shores of the Mediterranean Sea in Libya, the newspaper writes. Most of them come from Eritrea, Somali [sic] and Nigeria. They are waiting for better weather conditions to cross the sea on the way to the European Union"[1]. This report is consistent with the idea, already discussed here, that there is a strong seasonal component to Eritrean refugee emigration to Europe caused by bad weather in Q1.  Now, I don't put much stock in the pronouncements of TASS (Cold War habits die hard), and predictably TASS overdoes it here. Welt am Sonntag actually reports more modestly that the number of refugees could be as low as 150000[2]. Though it is unlikely to have much of an effect on _this_ question, Welt am Sonntag does offer some reason to believe that the number of seaborne refugees will increase disproportionally because of the new legal barriers to land routes. By the way, Google's translation of Welt am Sonntag is only intermittently helpful and include cringe inducing headlines such as "Jew Law visited the "Jungle" in Calais." Not exactly clickbait.  -- [1] http://tass.ru/en/world/858268
[2] http://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article152460616/200-000-Fluechtlinge-warten-auf-Ueberfahrt-nach-Europa.html
Q4 numbers appear to be less than 10k and over the past 2 years, the Q1 numbers drop from Q4 (via Eurostat).  Could sneak above 10k, but chance is very small.

The UN Refugee Agency reports that Italy has received 6,589 refugees, as of 2/17[1], but only 2% of refugees in 2015 were Eritrean. I could have _sworn_ the same source claimed it was 25% when I saw this earlier this year. But even if the proportion of Eritreans increases by an order of magnitude, that still predicts only 659 refugees half of the way through Q1. And not all refugees are asylum seekers. I'm probably missing something big, but the number of Eritrean asylum seekers looks like it will be well under 10,000 in Q1. [1] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/country.php?id=105
No change, but just noticed that Eritreans make up 2% of the arrivals by sea in Italy since Jan 1 (so, about 132 people) and aren't separately tallied for Greece.
Eurostat numbers following the expected trend (low winter applications )  (Dec: 1380, Jan: 780, as of 2/17) and @Anneinak's post about relaxed restrictions on Eritrean refugees in Ethiopia

http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article58008 February 12, 2016 (ADDIS ABABA) – Some Eritrean refugees in Ethiopia say the government’s “out of camp policy”, which relaxed restrictions on Eritrean refugees has encouraged them against taking the desperate and dangerous sea crossings to Europe. Introduced in Ethiopia in 2010, the policy provides Eritrean refugees an opportunity to live in Addis Ababa and other towns of their choices if they have the necessary means to financially support themselves.
. . . 
“Previously I had plans to take dangerous journey to reach Europe via Sudan and Libyan Desert; but I dropped my decision after I was granted a work-permit that would allow me to be out of camp”, Baraki Tesfatsion told Sudan Tribune from the Ethiopian capital. . . . “I would rather stay here in Ethiopia until the repressive regime is overthrown and a democratic government is replaced”, he argued, further stressing that he would rather try to process a legal visa to Europe than take dangerous and illegal journey.
. . . 
"Every month, thousands of Eritreans flee to neighboring countries of Ethiopia, Djibouti and Sudan to escape different forms of rights abuses, including extrajudicial killings, indefinite national service, incommunicado detention, arbitrary arrest and torture. "The Red Sea nation has long-standing shoot-to-kill policy targeting those attempting to flee their own country and many have been shot to death by their own border guards.  According to Eritrean refugees, those caught to sneak out are thrown into inhuman prison facilities where they will be tortured and ultimately accused of treason, a charge punishable by death. "Most of them prefer to cross the Mediterranean Sea mainly heading to Italy for better life however thousands has drowned and lost their lives in the Mediterranean. Bereket Yisak, who returned back to Ethiopia after he fail to succeed reaching Israel told Sudan Tribune that many Eritreans who fall in the hands unscrupulous human traffickers are taken hostage and their family back at home are asked to pay ransom of an average $15,000 per head for their release.  If their relatives fail to pay, he said, Eritrean hostages will be tortured to death or else parts of their organs such as Kidneys will be harvested and are sold to people in need of it in wealthier nations. "According to Bereket, a lot of Eritrean refugees are abducted in Sudan and taken to Sinai where captors decide on the fate of the hostage. He adviced Eritreans to refrain from using smuggling trail.
. . . 
"Since 2014, the number of Eritreans seeking asylum in Europe particularly in Italy has soared making them the second largest group - after Syrians - to arrive in the European nation by boat; according to the United Nations Refugee Agency (UNHCR). "Refugees in Addis Ababa say they are better off in Ethiopia under the out of camp policy and they say the scheme has restrained tendency of considerable number Eritrean refugees from taking peril journeys to Sudan, Libya or further to Europe. "The refugees added they have benefited a lot from the governments “out of camp policy”
According to the refugees, the scheme has helped them find jobs in the informal sector.
“We are being treated here very well here. I am currently working in different places as an electrician. I earn good money”, said 27-year old Gideon Samuel. “At the camps we had nothing to do but the out of camp policy has given us freedom of movement enabling us to work and support ourselves and not to be dependent on the government or Aid agencies”, added Gideon. He further said, living in cities has enabled refugees to improve their access to a lot of services which are not available at camps.
. . . 
Previously the UN refugee agency has resettled thousands of Eritrean refugees in Ethiopia to different western countries under its third country resettlement program. Despite the limited quota, third country resettlement program to Eritrean refugees remains effective both in terms meeting the needs of vulnerable groups and as a durable solution to a limited number of refugees.
. . . 
UNHCR says there is a plan to increase resettlement opportunities for refugees in Ethiopia in the coming years, including for Eritrean refugees. Ethiopia currently hosts a total of over 700,000 refugees of whom 170,000 are Eritrean refugees sheltered in four refugee camps in the northern Tigray region bordering Eritrea.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:   Yet another reason why the number won't exceed 10k.

Given the following info that Ethiopia is allowing Eritrean refugees to establish in Adds Abeba, I am raising the numbers for <10, and lowering a bit on 10-15, I put >15 at 1 because, let's face it, nothing is impossible -:) -:) ) http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article58008 I am
Eritrea to Europe, jeez, not a question - just how to make the trek. and over 10,000 will, esp. as the window may be closing fast.

Some interesting developments out of Addis Ababa: "Some Eritrean refugees in Ethiopia say the government’s “out of camp policy”, which relaxed restrictions on Eritrean refugees has encouraged them against taking the desperate and dangerous sea crossings to Europe."[1] I'm downgrading slightly the probability that the number of Eritrean asylum seekers will be 10,000 or higher. And, for Pete's sake, let's hope the situation improves for the Eritreans.  [1] http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article58008
No reason to expect any sudden surge during Q1 2016
Eurostat shows 755 first time asylum applicants from Eritrea in January 2016.
Fixing a mathematical error in last night's forecast.

No recent quarter has seen more than 15000 migrants so the probabilites of more than 15 000 are very small - 0% On the other hand, migration from Eritrea is made through sea crossing from Northern Africa to Southern Italy and so it becomes a lot more difficult during winter. During 2015, there were no more than 3700 Eritreans entering Europe in Q1, and during Q2 there were only 8400. It is very unlikely that there will be more than 10000 before Q3 Factors that can counter the forecast: - exceptional good weather in the Mediterranean
- unforeseen political pressure in Northern Africa implying a sudden flux of refugees across the Mediteranean to Italy

I put a lot more thought into this but changed by forecast very little. The grizzly details are here: https://pythagorassite.wordpress.com/2016/02/11/how-many-eritrean-citizens-will-apply-for-asylum-in-europe-for-the-first-time-in-the-first-quarter-of-2016/
trends are likely to continue albeit at a less accelerated pace of growth - in 2015 there were 37,000 refugees estimated.
The outbreak of war access the strait in Yemen and the continuing affect of an easier path through Libya make an upward trend likely.

I conducted my own dive into the data at: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/submitViewTableAction.do
I am unsure wether this questions asks about applications in Europe (the continent, as the question suggests) or the EU-28, as the description suggests. Should be a bit more specific. For the EU-28:
Even if the number for the missing countries in december levels the exact number in november, it will lead to +90 so far unreported applications. That would make up for 7.755+90 = 7.845 first time asyl applications in the fourth quarter of 2015.  For Europe:
Even if the number for the missing countries in december levels the exact number in november, it will lead to +271 so far unreported applications. That would make up for 9.160+271 = 9.431 first time asyl applications in the fourth quarter of 2015. None of these surpasses 10.000 for the fourth quarter of 2015. It is highly unlikely that it will do so in the first quarter of 2016. Adjusting my forecast to 100 - 0 - 0 because I have invested in the 10+ section for some time. @morrell @Dima-K

taking note of @Dima-K and @morrell https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/124918
- thanks! The number for the fourth quarter of 2015 will surpass 10k; in the past two years it went down half for the first quarter of the following year.
Although there has been mild weather in december and still kind of until now, the december data will not push the number over 20.000; so less than 10k still seems like a save forecast. no change for now.

If 2015 Q4 is similar to previous quarter or 2014 Q4 it will mean approximately 7-9000 applicants in 2015 Q4 bringing the total to about 30,000 for 2015 or an average of about 7500 per quarter.  Since this is a prediction for q1 2016 and q1 2015 was considerably lower than all other quarters I am led to believe that it is going to follow a similar pattern and be lower.  My prediction is that the number of Eritrean applicants in Q1 2016 is lower than 10,000. Only two previous quarters have been higher than 10000. Q1 seems to have lower applicants perhaps due to the weather concerns? I don't see evidence to make me believe that Q1 should behave differently than historical numbers say but will seek out contrary evidence in the coming days. If Q4 2015 numbers are dramatically higher than what I estimate I will revisit and alter my prediction.  I have seen other forecasters on GJopen saying that Q4 2015 had between 6700-8200 applicants which fits my guess above.  2013-2014 data (http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/images/d/d5/Countries_of_origin_of_%28non-EU%29_asylum_seekers_in_the_EU-28_Member_States%2C_2013_and_2014_YB15_III.png) Q3 2014-Q3 2015 data (http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/images/f/f1/First_time_asylum_applicants_in_the_EU-28_by_citizenship%2C_Q3_2014_%E2%80%93_Q3_2015.png)
I'm very impressed by the work already done by @morrell, @Paddyboy11, and others on this topic, though I haven't chewed through the data enough to be as certain as they.
Asylum applications have historically been lower in Q1. However Eritrean EU asylum applications overall increased in 2015

Although past data is not necessarily a guide to future numbers, Q1 figures for Eritrean migration have been consistently lower from 2013-2015 than other quarters. I would currently predict around 5,000 for Q1 2016.

Q4 2013 6030
Q1 2014 3055 Q4 2014 7030
Q1 2015 3155 Q4 2015 8740 (according to @morrell http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/98411

previous first quarter was very weak, trend seems slowing, EU started to react to slow down the refugee influx and so far nothing big did happen in q1 2016, which would make me doubt previous trends etc... 
http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/File:First_time_asylum_applicants_in_the_EU-28_by_citizenship,_Q3_2014_%E2%80%93_Q3_2015.png Brief review of top rated comments seems to suggest that it's not too wild esitmate
Numbers in Q1/2015 were at appr. 3000, Q3/2014 at appr. 15k, Q3/2015 less than 15k. Rainfall was certainly 40% lower than average, but politics seem to change in positive directions.
Once again a great analysis by @Paddyboy11, finding a solid predictive variable and good data sets. Go big or go home (or go Eurozone and apply for asylum).
First quarter rates are quite low and there was a big fall in the year-on-year third quarter applications.

It is most likely to be less than 10,000 due to poorer travel conditions during the winter, however, it is not impossible that a greater number will apply for asylum due to poor living conditions and reports from friends and family living in the EU about the increased quality of life
No war, no famine, and spreading news of difficulties faced by would-be immigrants will limit the number of Erirean candidates.

Whilst the number of Eritrean refugees entering Europe appears to increase from year to year, it will still probably not exceed 10000 in a 3 month period. UNHCR reports that on the first six months of 2015 a total of 67,500 refugees entered Europe by boat, the preferred method of entry for Eritreans. It is estimated that 25% of these were Eritrean refugees (16,875). So even if the number of refugees exceeds 2015 numbers, it's still over 1000 additional refugees needed in the first 3 months to exceed 10,000. However it is possible, hence the 20% chance of 10-15

The tricky part of this question is the UN's distinction between fleeing for economic reasons and fleeing due to persecution.  Eritrea is one of the world's fastest emptying countries.  During the first 8 months of last year, the EU took in 16690 Asylum seekers, roughly 90% of which were granted asylum.  The number of citizens fleeing to the EU rose from ~11,000 in 2011 to ~46,000 in 2014.  However, if the first 8 months in the EU saw ~17,000 emigrants in 8 months, that comes to about 25,000 in 2015, which indicates the sheer numbers have slowed.   For the sake of this exercise we'll say the number has stayed the same, so the first 4 months of 2016 would see ~8,000 migrants. http://www.wsj.com/articles/eritreans-flee-conscription-and-poverty-adding-to-the-migrant-crisis-in-europe-1445391364?alg=y
http://www.cfr.org/eritrea/authoritarianism-eritrea-migrant-crisis/p37239
High success rate amongst those made the journey will encourage others.

As Eritrea is surrounded by Sudan and Ethiopia, it would continue to be in a region of turmoil with no stable government. Although a lot of migrants have left eritrea for Europe over the past few years leading to a big headache for European Immigration authorities there has been no effort to improve the situation in eritrea itself by providing aid or good governance which may help in stemming the flow. The flow of Eritreans across the deadliest migrant trail will continue.. IMHO.
Based on UNHCR measures for 2015, and trend data.

Eurostat data indicates that average migrants per qtr was just under 8,000. Press comment on economic migrant numbers that "actual numbers were likely to be higher as Finland only country to submit data up to November." Checking Frontex Q3 Risk Analysis shows much higher number of detected illegal border crossings from Eritreans, 17,440 Q2  and 16,487 Q3 of last year. No Eritreans were identified as having been refused admission. My current estimation of probabilities is skewed to reflect but more work to be done. Sources:- http://frontex.europa.eu/assets/Publications/Risk_Analysis/FRAN_Q3_2015.pdf
http://tsfanews.net/60-percent-economic-migrants-eu-refugees

Baseline from 2015: 2,086.25 applicants per month from Eritrea to EU. The EU was accepting at a 90% rate although whether that percentage increases/decreases is irrelevant since the question calls for simply applications.  If the trend from the 1st 8 months of 2015 holds true you would have 6,258 applications.  Because the acceptance rate is 90% I'll multiple 6,258 by .9 (assuming a full reapplication rate from the 10% that are denied - this is an in exact #). The result is 5,632 applications. With 5,632 applications as the baseline, I offer the below adjustments: (+)The last 5 months (May-Sept 2015) showed a marked increase over the first three months, averaging close to 4,000 a month. (+)On Jan 26th the Eritrean government announced a 'two wives policy' calling for men to marry two women or be forced to jail for life (replenishing population due to Civil War w/ Ethopia. Based on recent upward trend and recent government decisions that will likely contribute to growing numbers of asylum seekers, I find it reasonably likely that asylum seekers will surpass 10,000. Keep in mind, total population is likely less than 6M (6.333 as of 2013) so there is a fairly low ceiling. (-)
They are discouraged from formally applying
Based on Eurostat's most recent figures and assuming slight reduction due to weather and EU measures to control flow of migrants.

Approximately 3200 Eritreans sought asylum in Europe in the first quarter of 2015 according to the UNHCR, which was slightly less than the first quarter of 2014, so the quarterly amount is trending downward.  There is nothing indicating that conditions in Eritrea are any worse now than in the first quarters of 2014 and 2015.  Hence, it is unlikely that the number of Eritrean asylum seekers in the first quarter of 2016 would deviate considerably from prior years.
Weather constraints, immigrant-phobia on the rise, Germany resisting, more border constraints constraints controls

The question is how many asylum applicants from Eritrea. Not how may are granted asylum. There were 31,000 EU asylum seekers from Eritrea last year. Most came from Libya to Italy by crossing the Mediterranean. Only 3,310 applied for asylum in the first quarter of 2015, which is probaly because of winter weather conditions.  Eritrea is overpopulated country with no economy to speak of.   Irregardless of the government or the enforced conscription, thousands will continue to try and escape from Eritrea. If  EU border controls and migration rules change, it will take time to implement the changes. Therefore, it is a 80% chance that Europe will have the same amount of Eritrean asylum seekers as they did last year.
Following @einsteinjs, who is, I believe, following @Paddyboy11!

Jumping in at 100% for less than 10k. I normally wouldn't do something like this, but after seeing @Paddyboy11's analysis (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/96197), it's hard *not* to join in, especially because the "consensus" still has that bin at 73% (as of this prediction). I checked the numbers from Germany ( http://www.bamf.de/SharedDocs/Anlagen/DE/Downloads/Infothek/Statistik/Asyl/201512-statistik-anlage-asyl-geschaeftsbericht.pdf?__blob=publicationFile ) and Belgium ( http://www.cgvs.be/sites/default/files/asielstatistieken_december_2015_0.pdf ) as well. There are not as detailed as the report from the IND, but their overall numbers for 2015 compared to 2014 show a decline in applications.

The only way there could be more than 10k is if Eritreans not currently in Eritrea are included in the count. And that would only happen if those currently residing somewhere else perceive that Europe is a better gamble than where they are. Otherwise, the population is too poor and too far away.

New report from the Dutch Immigration Service (IND). https://ind.nl/Documents/Asylum%20Trends%20December%202015.pdf The number of first time applications from Eritreans in Q4 2015  was approximately 4 times the number of applicants in Q4 2014 (135 vs. 32). The number of first time applications from Eritreans in the EU-28 in Q1 2015 was 3155 (according to the Eurostat-report that GJ links to), although the IND reports that the number of first time applications in the EU-26 (excluding Norway and Switzerland) in Q1 was actually higher: 3830. Anyway, if you combine the numbers above in an absolutely unscientific way - (135/32)*[EU Q1 2015] - you'll get 13310 and 16157 respectively. Adjusting upwards.

This is a strange one -- lots of variance from top forecasters with data to back up every opinion. I'm going to try and keep things simple, sticking to base rate and assuming that last year's seasonal patterns will be similar to this year's. Both of these data sources point to a low number of applications, while the 15,000+ predictions I've seen tend to hinge on more complicated explanations about "bottlenecks" and application strategies. These complicated explanations may well pan out, but I'll stick with simplicity for now and watch the crowd's view carefully.  Also, I'm placing a bit less probability on 10-15 than might be expected, given that I allow the possibility of 15,000+. If the number is higher than 10,000, that could easily be because something threw the conservative model way off -- in which case, I'd like to be prepared for an extreme outcome. Given that between 10,000 and 20,000 people ask for asylum, I'd give roughly 25% odds that the number is between 15,000 and 20,000. Other thoughts: * Compared to asylum-seekers from most other nations, Eritreans are almost all between the ages of 18 and 34. This implies that single people are moving to find employment (and perhaps send remittances), since few children are applying. Employment could imply seasonal migration (e.g. for farming), which might account for the steadiness we see in how rates fluctuate by quarter. This is a complex explanation, and I don't put much weight on it, but it's in the back of my mind. (Another explanation for the age range -- that refugees are fleeing conscription into national service -- isn't necessarily seasonal, which is one strike against this view.) * Developments in the "ongoing authoritarian crisis" in Eritrea don't seem likely to cause massive shifts in migration. The things that often worry human rights organizations (dissidents thrown in prison, crackdowns on the media) may not be all that impactful for the population at large. War in Syria affects all Syrians; political tyranny in Eritrea seems like it would affect a much smaller portion of Eritreans (especially given that the situation in Eritrea isn't especially  new or unpredictable).

According to the UNHCR, the typical path for Eritrean asylum seekers is through Libya, across the Mediterranean to Italy by boat and then by hook or by crook to a rich nation: UK, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Norway for asylum.  I plotted the monthly Italian arrival data from 2014 against the monthly asylum seeker data. I'm not sure the data is 100% accurate in the most recent months. I found a compelling graphical correlation (and a 91% correlation coefficient!) by first taking a 3-month rolling average and using that as my inputs.  Then lagging the arrival data by 1 month, so I'm comparing last month's arrivals to this month's asylum seekers. So I think it makes sense to ignore any airplane, land travelers, and Greeks and focus on the December, January, and February arrivals.  My linear regression indicates that the 1st quarter total will be 3,000 plus 69% of those Italian arrivals. In the first 17 days of January there are 280 Eritreans arrived in Italy, I'll gross this up to 500.  I can't find the December data, but in November there were 86 arrivals. In December of the prior year there were 317 in November and 140 in December.  I will put this at 200.  In February it was 646 and 253 the last two years, I'll put it at 500.  This gets me to a 1200 arrival lagged estimate and a regression estimate of 3800 arrivals. One way to check the model is to predict the asylum seekers in Q4 2015. Someone has posted on here that they found it, but I couldnt verify it.  the model predicts 7900 asylum seekers in the 4th quarter. @PStauble claims there are 6700 asylum seekers in Q4 2015.   @morrell more recently claims there are 8200 asylum seekers in Q4 2015.  Both cite Eurostat data I havent yet verified.  This is close enough for me, strong validation of the model.  Seems very difficult for this to creep above 10,000 based on the slowdown in Italy arrivals. UPDATE: The December number has been posted, much higher than expected at 1,280 Eritreans.  I had predicted 200, but I think this overage in large part is due to 1,000 of them arriving in Sicily on Christmas.  No sign of this being a repeated event subsequently.  This changes my point estimate to 4,500 asylum applications in the first quarter of 2017. Still a very long way from 10,000.

First quarter volume is not there to justify uptick.

Based on my analysis of Eurostat numbers, I’m coming up with a strong probability for under 10K. For those of you reviewing Eurostat numbers, there are two tables in their database related to asylum seekers – “Asylum” and “First Time Asylum Applicants.” Based on the wording of the question, the latter category is the one to consider. (The delta between the numbers from these tables is enough to make a difference.) During the 1st quarter of the last four years, (2012-2015), the number of Eriteans filing for first time asylum applications has not exceeded 10K. Based on data from previous years, the spike in applicants occurs in the second and third quarters, respectively.  Therefore, it remains possible that the number of Eriteans filing for first time asylum will eventually exceed 10K for a quarter…but it seems unlikely to occur in the 1st quarter.  <10K = 90%
(10-15) Between 10,000 and 15,000, inclusive= 9%
(>15) More than 15,000 = 1%

Of the 5 quarters, 3 had <10,000 Eritrean asylum-seekers and 2 had between 10,000 and 15,000. However, not every European country in which Eritreans seek asylum is in the EU. Although there's not a lot of data, I see a seasonal pattern where Q2 and Q3 are the high frequency migration quarters, and Q1 and Q4 being lower, and Q1 being the lowest. I suspect this reflects the desire to cross the sea in the milder spring and summer seasons. Data from the UN Refugee Agency (which closely matches Eurostat data) shows 3760 Asylum seekers in October and 1987 in November. 4Q2015 is likely to finish with around 7500 asylum seekers. Q1 figures have been lower than Q4 in the past. What's more, conditions in Eritrea appear to be getting better. Forced conscription is alleged to be limited to 18 months to 4 years, whereas before it was indefinite. And, a few EU countries have been sending asylum seekers back to Eritrea as a result of alleged better conditions. Thus, demand to go to the EU is likely dampened.

Based on Eurostat and UNHCR data. Q1 is a poor time in Eritrea for asylum seeking due to the unpredictable poor winter conditions. This is backed up by historic data. While annual figures have spiked in the past two years it has fallen YoY over the same period. No additional internal factors have arisen to cause a further spike over that of the past two years since conscription. There are some possibilities which might cause this such as revolution or war with Ethiopia but I cannot find evidence that these should be given much weight. Ethiopia and Sudan are much larger and more immediate destinations for Eritrean refugees and these haven't seen a spike. This may be offset by increased unrest in Sudan but 10k is triple the number of the prior year which itself tripled have fluctuated down. Tripling YoY is an event which suggests total collapse such as caused by Syrian conflicts. This is not the case in Eritrea.

Whilst 37 thousand applicants submitted asylum applications in 2014 (according to Eurostat) the Q3 like for like applications for 2015 were lower. Also historically asylum applications in Q1 tend to be lower than as for the year as a whole.
First quarter appears to be a slow quarter for migration from Eritrea.  averaging around 12,000 a quarter over last couple years.
No way Europe lets more people in than necessary, and Eritreans don't have more than 10,000 necessary people for Europe.

In Q1 2015 the number of Eritreans was about 4% of the 190,000 total EU asylum applicants (so about 7500 to 8000). The total quarterly numbers of EU asylum applicants increased by the percentage of Eritreans went down to about 3%, meaning the quarterly number of Eritreans remained fairly constant. Therefore I would expect Q1 2016 to be between 7000 and 9000.

"In a bill that the Ministerial Legislation Committee will likely discuss on Sunday, the party advocates financial incentives for towns that accept the African migrants, in order to reduce their crowding in south Tel Aviv. "The chances of a bill submitted by the opposition to win the cabinet ministers’ support are slim. The move is mainly intended to present to the public a significant alternative to Netanyahu’s government’s policy in recent years.
. . . 
"The party suggests approving the bill as a temporary provision for five years, to examine its effect on the lives of south Tel Aviv residents and on the migrants.  Under the proposal, the interior minister will grant the migrants a year’s permit to stay in Israel and extend it every year, as needed. The migrants will receive health insurance and a work permit.
. . . 
“We see the main mission of this bill to put an end to the tragedy of south Tel Aviv,” she said.
The bill cites the State Comptroller’s report that said “the situation in the five south Tel Aviv neighborhoods where a considerable number of the migrants live is complicated and filled with hardships. There’s no doubt that the residents’ quality of life has been seriously harmed and the neighborhoods have been changed unrecognizably.”
. . . 
" . . . According to the Population Registrar’s figures, some 185,000 migrants are currently staying in Israel, 77,000 of them legally and 16,000 illegally. Some 90,000 are classified as tourists staying in Israel with no visa. “We won’t double the number of work migrants in Israel, but disperse those who are already here in places where they’re needed,” she said.
“The state will be able, for example, to stop importing new foreign workers and use those who are already here. This proposal will make them beneficial. For a long time the authorities buried their head in the sand and preferred not to give them a legal status because they were afraid of them,” she said.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Just the introduction of such legislation will improve the perception of Israel as a place of asylum for Eritreans, which might reduce the number seeking asylum in Europe.  I'm considering raising my forecast for under 10k.

@andrewsabisky Take a look at this article, detailing the "bottleneck" of migrants in the Calais camp, some there for six months, as they wait for entry into Britain. I imagine this scene is playing out throughout Europe's migrant camps: Migrants reluctant to file for asylum in countries where they feel they'd be victimized, so they withhold their asylum applications for months until they reach friendlier countries. What the exact mechanism is for transfer from less desirable European countries to the countries of choice, and how quickly and efficiently this mechanism is working, is not clear from this article, but it buttresses my belief that the wave of migrants in the latter half of 2015 will result in a staggered wave of asylum applications early this year.

From the data reported by EuroStats, it appears that the number of asylum seekers drops by about 1/2 in the first quarter of most years (compared with quarter 3 or 4). Quarter 3 of 2015 shows around 11,000 first time asylum seekers, and it is likely that the Q4 numbers will be similar. 
Taking the recent engagement with Saudi Arabia against Yemen, the Eritrean economy may see a boost in fuel and money, and the citizens will be employed within the military. This may decrease the numbers of refugees somewhat, if we believe that the main reason for the exodus is freedom and wealth. On the other hand, an increase in Sunni presence (from Saudi Arabia and interactions with the Middle East), will likely increase the persecution of religious minorities (such as Christians), thus increasing the numbers of refugees. However, these recent developments are unlikely to show up in the Q1 data.
This is an opportunity that many will make use of.

Eritrea is what seems to be, a pretty terrible country. Founded in April 1993, after a bloody and costly war of independence with Ethiopia, the State of Eritrea has been ruled with an iron fist by Isaias Afwerki, former leader of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front. Eritrea regularly ranks at the bottom of pretty much every global ranking, from religious freedom to human rights, including a noteworthy bottom position for the world press freedom rankings (below North Korea). The country is renowned for its lifelong conscription, where young men are forced to serve the government indefinitely with a pay of under 2 USD per day. Defectors, resisters and political opponents are regularly imprisoned and add to the ranks of the estimated 10,000 political prisoners serving sentences at the pleasure of the state and its extensive secret police force. Systemic violence, fear, sexual abuse, corruption, torture and murder are a regular part of everyday life in modern Eritrea.
	The ever deteriorating situation in Eritrea has unsurprisingly caused a significant number of its citizens to flee in search of better lives and an escape from persecution. In 2015 alone over 30,000 Eritrean asylum seekers arrived in the EU for the first time. As of June 2015, the UNHCR estimates that there are over 440,000 asylum seekers and refugees worldwide originating from Eritrea - a country with a population of around 6 million people. In Q1 of 2015, there were 3155 applications for asylum from Eritrean citizens for the first time in the EU. Plotting the data shows that Q1 is historically a numerical low point for Eritrean refugees arriving in Europe. Q1 2014 had 2,940 arriving and Q12015 had a slightly higher number at 3,155. Unsurprisingly the numbers have grown significantly since the 2012 Arab Spring threw Libya and Egypt, the two main countries between Eritrea and Europe, into varying degrees of chaos. 
	My initial prediction is that the Q1 2016 numbers will be similar to those of the previous two years - around 3,000 persons. To try and estimate how this number may be wrong, I decided to look at three things: the starting country, the journey and the destination. My goal was to determine if any of these factors would cause an increase from the 3,000 outside value I predicted.
	Looking at the current situation in Eritrea shows that, although it does not seem to be a great place to live, it is not getting much worse. Many theories even point towards it getting better. Eritrea has achieved several development goals put forward by the UN and has in the last years had significant success in reducing the spread of HIV. The government is currently in talks with neighbouring countries to “bring it out of the cold”, and a number of European nations have reacted to the large number of refugees by suggesting that sanctions against Eritrea should be lessened so that the country can be allowed to develop economically. There are even persisting rumours that the national service will soon be decreased or changed. Although things are not getting better, they don’t seem to be getting much worse at the moment. 
On the other hand, there are prevalent theories that the government is encouraging people to leave - or at the very least not discouraging them. Around 20 to 30% of Eritrea's GDP comes from Eritreans living abroad, either in the form of remittance payments or in the form of taxes which the Eritrean government levies on its citizens no matter where they live. It is not inconceivable that the government could be encouraging a diaspora in an attempt to boost the economy. Despite this possibility, I think that if this was the planned tactic of the government it would be more obvious, and would already have been either publicly condemned or at the very least already have had an impact on the number of refugees and be reflected in the statistical analysis. Generally, looking at Eritrea I get the overall impression that the country is completely stagnant. This leads me to believe that there will probably not be any significant changes occurring this quarter that will cause the people to flee Eritrea even more than they have in the last two years.
The second aspect to look at is the route to Europe. In the last few years the path to Europe has become ever easier for Eritrean refugees. Previously the Libyan border to the North was relatively well defended and acted as somewhat of a barrier for Eritreans moving up to northern Africa and the Mediterranean. Additionally, many other countries have started expelling Eritrean refugees. Notable examples include Israel, which has gotten stricter with the treatment of African refugees in recent years - most infamously by building a wall along the Egyptian border in 2012 and expelling large numbers of refugees in recent months. This tightening of the Israeli borders has forced refugee flows to move further north towards the Mediterranean where they can try their luck in Europe.
Another relevant factor for the journey is the relatively mild winter that Europe has enjoyed so far. In 2014 and 2015 the minimum weekly temperature in Malta averaged between 8 and 12 degrees in January and February, and was slightly higher in March. In January alone the average weekly minimum has already been closer to 14 degrees. Nicer weather obviously makes the trip significantly less risky and uncomfortable and increases the chances that the number of refugees attempting to come to Europe by sea will increase. Of course, a number of other refugees will attempt the route overland by plane, car, train or other methods and through other routes. However, I do not believe that the number of persons taking these types of routes will be significantly affected by the weather.
On the other hand, although the weather may make a crossing easier, the European Union has significantly increased its fight against smugglers in recent months. The ongoing media and political focus on people smugglers transporting the ever increasing number of refugees to Europe has lead to massively increased interest and investment in policing the seas and attempting to stop smugglers from even bringing people across to Europe. I think that compared to Q1 2014 and Q1 2015 these missions will already have a significant impact on making the journey from Africa to Europe even more difficult. However, the fact that smugglers and travel routes have in the meantime already become well established and well practiced may serve to mitigate the impact that increased police and military focus on the issue has.
Finally, I think the destination of Europe is becoming increasingly unattractive and inhospitable for refugees. I believe that the goodwill that the EU has shown, championed mainly by Angela Merkel, will not be permanent and that isolated events like the New Year attacks in Köln will lead to increased antipathy against refugees and immigrants. Politicians hoping to win easy points with the public are already capitalising on the fear of foreigners and policies regarding refugees are already starting to become stricter. I think this means that the EU will work to increase funding for border protection, will make the process for registering as an asylum seeker or refugee even more difficult and will start to do more and more to deter refugees from coming to Europe. However, this reaction most likely will not have a huge effect in Q1 of 2016, but will probably be felt by refugees coming later in the year. And despite this, living in the EU is most likely still better than living stateless in an Ethiopian refugee camp or serving for life in the Eritrean military. Eritrean refugees simply have so little to lose and so much to potentially gain that I think very few changes in policy in the EU would make them not want to come there. Therefore I think that political changes within the EU will have a minimal impact on the number of refugees wanting to or trying to reach the shores of Europe.
Overall, my analysis so far indicates that the numbers may increase slightly over last year due to the mild weather, but also that this effect may be somewhat mitigated by increased investment in border control in the EU. Of course there are other outliers that may be unexpected, but have a significant impact on the number of refugees. One not completely unlikely scenario is that Eritrea's conflict with Ethiopia starts again. This would not only likely displace a large number of Eritreans, but potentially also lead to the expulsion of the large Eritrean diaspora living in Ethiopia. Many of these refugees would move north towards Europe rather than be caught in the fight. However, the conflict has not erupted into full blown fighting in several years, and I see the chances of it happening in the next 2.5 months as rather unlikely. A second factor could be a change in the level of conflict in Libya. Currently I think that Libya has just the right amount of chaos to facilitate refugees in reaching Europe. Any more conflict and I think it would become very difficult for large groups of refugees to travel through Libya. Any less conflict and the government (if a true government existed) would be forced/supported by the EU to stop the flow. I do not see any significant changes happening in Libya in the next months that would change the status quo there significantly. The same appears to be the case in Egypt. The UNHCR states that continued instability in Egypt, combined with a lack of resources, has made it easy for refugees to travel through the country and up to Europe. The UNHCR predicted that this would be the case all through 2015 (it was) and I don’t see any significant enough changes within Egypt to indicate that this will suddenly change in Q1 2016.
Putting all this together I think that the lack of change in Eritrea, Egypt and Libya will mean that the numbers will stay around 3,000 persons. It is possible that the mild winter could mean an increase to around 5,000. I also think it is possible to increase if the government of Eritrea actively allows or forces people to leave. However, I do not believe that the number will more than triple from the last two years and reach the 10,000 mark unless there is a truly significant event in Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia or Libya. Since these countries are quite big, quite unstable, and quite unpredictable, I say there is a 12% chance that some event will occur that will push the number up to between 10 and 15,000 refugees - as was the case in Q2 2014 (11,140) or Q3.2015 (12,220) - when the weather was nicer than it is now. I think there is an 8% chance that the mild weather (or some other completely unexpected event) will completely cause the flow of refugees to overwhelm Europe's borders and lead to numbers closer to those of Q3 2014 (15,145). I do think that the overall numbers of refugees will increase, however I really don’t predict an increase in the number of Eritreans, as their incentives and opportunities just haven’t changed enough to cause such a huge shift. Just looking over the numbers very quickly, my gut feeling is that, for at least some Eritreans, there is a few months lag between when an Eritrean enters Europe, and when their first time asylum application is logged. If the 4% of sea migrants being Eritrea is generally consistent month to month, as per UNHCR, then Jan 2015 should have seen about 222 Eritrean migrants. Yet according to Eurostat, 1295 Eritreans applied for asylum in Jan 2015. Eritrean asylum seekers are greater than my estimated Eritrean migrants for every month until August 2015, suggesting that migrants from the rush of mid-to-late 2014 submit applications in early-to-mid 2015. If that's true, I'd suggest that about 26,000 Eritreans (4% of all sea migrants in Q4 2015) will seek asylum in Q1 2016. Still, I think I'd need to take a deeper dive into the UNHCR numbers, but for the time being I'll come down on slightly over 15,000.

Asylum applications in the Europe have been on an upward trajectory since 2006.  The number of asylum applications to the EU more than doubled from 2013 to 2014 and increased further still last year. 
The caseload from Eritrea saw the third largest jump between 2013 and 2014, an 154.9% increase in applications on the previous year (http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/images/d/d5/Countries_of_origin_of_%28non-EU%29_asylum_seekers_in_the_EU-28_Member_States%2C_2013_and_2014_YB15_III.png). However, the total number of Eritrean asylum applicants in 2015 actually fell compared to 2014 levels  by approximately 5,000 cases (http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/File:First_time_asylum_applicants_in_the_EU-28_by_citizenship,_Q3_2014_%E2%80%93_Q3_2015.png) - contrary to other critical caseloads whose numbers continued to rise. 
Eritrean asylum applicants by quarter: 
Q3 2015: 11,685
Q2 2015: 9, 185
Q1 2015: 3,155
Q4 2014: 7,030
Q3 2014: 15,145
Q2 2014: 11,135
Q1 2014: 2,940
Fewer applications are habitually made in Q1 across all caseloads (likely due to difficulties in traveling over winter months) and the number of Eritrean asylum applications has never been over 15,000 for any one quarter even in the busiest times.  I’m using apx 3,000 asylum applicants in 2016 Q1 as a base number.
Eritrea is also accepting funds from the EU development package aimed at reducing migration from the Horn of Africa which might reduce the nearly 5,000 people per month that the UN says flee the country. However, the context continues to be highly unstable and tense relationships with Ethiopia coupled with increasing dissent could provoke a conflict or major crackdown that would create higher levels of displacement.

In the first 8 months of 2015 around 16.000 arrived. The first quarter is winter, and the EU may well decide to redouble their efforts to keep them out. It doesn't seem likely to me that more should arrive.
The average number of asylum claimnants is decreasing + recent political developments in Europe will diminish incentives to claim asylum.

Checked the UNHCR spreadsheet for Italy & Malta arrivals Jan-Nov, bears out sharp winter reduction in Eritrean refugee arrivals.  Eritrean arrivals in Italy over Jan-Nov were almost 38K (not necessarily first time applicants for asylum).  ( http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/download.php?id=362 )  Eritrea not broken out separately as country of origin for arrivals in Greece.

Based on Eurostat
http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/File:First_time_asylum_applicants_in_the_EU-28_by_citizenship,_Q3_2014_%E2%80%93_Q3_2015.png It appears 3rd quarter 2015 is down from 3rd quarter 2014.  Thus there may be a downward trend. In addition, there is there was a Danish report (sorry I closed it and can't find the link again) that reported conditions in Eritrea are improving. A human rights organization claimed it was too soon to report that, they were still investigating... but the numbers at Eurostat seem to bear it out.

Based on data from 2008 at Eurostat, the broad trend seems to be roughly 5k Eriterians applying per year from 2008-2012, followed by an increase to 14k in 2013, and 36k in 2014.  So far in 2015, the number of Eriterian asylum seekers has declined somewhat from 2014 (there was a 23% decline from 2014 Q3 to 2015 Q3) .  The numbers in the first quarter have generally about 15%-20% of the annual numbers, with a maximum of 3k in the first quarter of 2015. Given the general decline in the number of Eriterian asylum seekers,  3k is probably a good median estimate for Q1 of 2016 as well.  It would take a huge increase to reach 10k or 15k; such an increase is possible (there was a 679% increase in asylum seekers from 2013 Q2 to 2014 Q2) but would be against the current declining trend.
For 2015, Kosovo is #3 and Albania is #5. Thank you, Bill Clinton.

3,155 in Q1 2015, 9,185 in Q2 2015, 11,685 in Q3 2015. FIgures for Q4 not yet released, but potentially may be slightly higher than Q3 (http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php#_ga=1.84678558.689113864.1451423879 shows that October 2015 was the peak month for refugees crossing the Med to Europe - with Eritreans representing 4% of the annual total in 2015) As of the latest figures (let us presume they are to Jan 10th, but it could be earlier), the number of refugees crossing the Med numbers 18,384 in Jan 2016, compared with 5,550 for the whole 31 days of Jan 2015.  Doing a quick and dirty multiplication of this figure by 3, presuming a similar rate of traffic for the whole month we get a potential inflow to Europe of around 54,000 for the month - 10x that of Jan last year. Making the presumption that similar trends continue in Feb, we could see 72,000 cross-Med refugees in that month (7,271 in Feb 2015). and 100,000 in March (10,424 in March 2015). We don't know what proportion of this figure is equated for by Eritreans. Unaware of any major political change that could make the desire for refugees to leave the extremely repressive state of Eritrea - so let us presume the rate remains the same as overall for last year - 4%.  = 4% of (54,000 + 72,000 + 100,000)  = 9,040.  This figure also doesn't account for Eritreans who reach Europe by other routes than crossing the Med.  However, the EU stats at http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/images/f/f1/First_time_asylum_applicants_in_the_EU-28_by_citizenship%2C_Q3_2014_%E2%80%93_Q3_2015.png do show that there was a downturn in applications from Eritrea of-23% between Q3 2014 and Q3 2015 Does the number of uncounted Eritrean refugees who enter the EU not via the Med represent a counterbalance to this 23% decline? Again, not sure. Libya route appears most likely - those arriving by plane directly to Europe from Eritrea,  only likely to be a tiny proportion, not least because Eritrea is one of the very few countries to impose exit visa requirements (stated in https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/459486/Eritrea_-_Illegal_Exit_-_v2_0e.pdf)

Revised estimate : Tightening of the political space within the EU with regard to migration and political refugees has increased in its intensity as its social and political space becomes more conflictual.  The number of political asylum seekers in 2015 is reported as 60,157.  Of the 60,157 first time applicants 6745 decisions were made in 2015; only 62% (4182) were granted asylee status.  The subjective probability estimate for 2016 for Eritrean applicants should be expected to be within the 10,000 or > 15,000 range.   This range will depend on data within the 4thQ yet to be reported. The total number of first time applicants for status as political refugees in the EU was approximately 410,000 in the third quarter of 2015. Eritrean applicants were 3% of that total (12,300).  Estimates indicate that the general trend is that there were significant increases in 2015 over 2014 numbers.   One can expect that the estimates for the first quarter of 2016 will not be significantly curtailed and could fall within the 4th quarter estimated range.   Change in estimate (due to incorrect submission of prediction) :  the trend toward >15 will depend on the constrains within the interpretation of changes in asylee law within the individual EU states. 15, 145 total for July, August and September 2014.  11,685 for same period 2015.  No data yet reported for 4Q 2015.  Eurostate indicates the following methodological observation:  'The number of first time asylum applicants[1][2] increased by more than 150 % in the third quarter of 2015 compared with the same quarter of 2014 and almost doubled compared with the second quarter of 2015. Overall, the number of persons seeking asylum from non-EU countries in the EU-28 during the third quarter of 2015 reached 413 800.'

According to CFR, in the first eight months of 2015, the EU received nearly 17,000 asylum applications from Eritrean citizens.  Given this statistic, it seems highly likely that in the first quarter of 2016, less than 10,000 Eritrean citizens will apply for asylum.
Eritrean route to Europe seems to be primarily through Libya.  So, a longer sea crossing seems to me to imply lower winter numbers - the one set of Q1 data (for 2015) perhaps supports this view
Obviously mis-read question. Not sure how quickly Europe may be able to implement any changes though in that time frame.
Reminds me of arctic ice question. If I read Table 1 correctly there were ~31k in the last year. I expect Europe will modify their current approach to migrants, but less than 15k seems a stretch.
